qas.question: What were VSDs lacking that CD-Vs included?
In what areas of the world were VSDs popular?

answers.text: only in Japan and other parts of Asia

qas.question: Were VSDs or CD-Vs all digital and also playable on DVD players?

context: CD-Vs are not to be confused with Video CDs (which are all-digital and can only be played on VCD players, DVD players, CD-i players, computers, and later-model LaserDisc players, such as the DVL series from Pioneer that can also play DVDs). CD-Vs can only be played back on LaserDisc players with CD-V capability. <a2_0>VSDs<a2_0/> were the same as CD-Vs, but without the <a0_0>audio CD tracks<a0_0/>. CD-Vs were somewhat popular for a brief time worldwide, but soon faded from view. VSDs were popular <a1_0>only in Japan and other parts of Asia<a1_0/>, and were never fully introduced to the rest of the world.
